page.title: 10PORT ELPHINSTONE INVERURIE
page.content:
Port Elphinstone stands at the southern end of Inverurie across the Inverurie, or Don, Bridge. In 1921 it became part of the burgh of Inverurie, but originally it was a separate township built at the terminus of the Aberdeenshire Canal.
The canal was built to transport goods from the Inverurie area to Aberdeen where they could be conveyed by sea. Thomas Telford designed the canal, which was officially opened in 1805. It was 19 miles long following the valley of the River Don to Aberdeen Harbour.
Passengers as well as freight were transported to and from Port Elphinstone. Slates, stones, dung, coal, lime and grain were the main goods carried.
